footsteps and with the businesslike, preoccupied, yet meekly Christian look which never left her face, Anna MikMylovna entered the hall. Though she came upon thecount in his dressing gown every day, he invariably became confused and begged her to excuse his costume. 
"No matter at all, my dear count," she said, meekly closing her eyes. "But I'll go to Bezuk- hov's myself. Pierre has arrived, and now we shall get anything we want from his hothouses. I have to see him in any case. He has fo
